content.raw: This is live as of yesterday in our lab. One thing that came up is that there should be a standard storage location instead of the `self.last_opened_shots_folder`. I would change the FileDialoges to always open the folder `(labscriptfolder)/userlib/runviewer_configs`(and create it if it doesn't exist) is that a good location or are there better places?
content.html: This is live as of yesterday in our lab. One thing that came up is that there should be a standard storage location instead of the self.last_opened_shots_folder. I would change the FileDialoges to always open the folder (labscriptfolder)/userlib/runviewer_configs(and create it if it doesn't exist) is that a good location or are there better places?

content.raw: No, I don't have a good suggestion. Configuration file storage is currently a giant mess in my view, and we need to discuss/create a standard across all the programs (as well as standardise on labconfig vs program config vs config for a particular experiment in a particular program). I would probably avoid creating a new folder to put things in, if only because the location will probably change once we sort this all out, and I'd rather not have lots of dead folders hanging around in people's installs (and programmatic deletion of folders is risky).
content.html: No, I don't have a good suggestion. Configuration file storage is currently a giant mess in my view, and we need to discuss/create a standard across all the programs (as well as standardise on labconfig vs program config vs config for a particular experiment in a particular program). I would probably avoid creating a new folder to put things in, if only because the location will probably change once we sort this all out, and I'd rather not have lots of dead folders hanging around in people's installs (and programmatic deletion of folders is risky).

content.raw:
I'm not sure whether you disagree or whether you weren't following when it happened, but the installer now adds a configuration setting to the default labconfig:

`app_saved_configs = %(labscript_suite)s/userlib/app_saved_configs/%(experiment_name)s`

As well as configuration setting in the [lyse] and [runmanager] sections:

`autoload_config_file = %(app_saved_configs)s/lyse/lyse.ini`

and

`autoload_config_file = %(app_saved_configs)s/runmanager/runmanager.ini`

So I thought this problem was resolved and that runviewer should use the `<app_saved_configs>/runviewer` directory, creating the `app_saved_configs` directory it if it doesn't exist for backward compatibility with config files that lack it.

Here is previous discussion:

#!/labscript_suite/lyse/pull-requests/18/added-ability-to-restore-ui-state/diff#comment-42123410
content.html:
I'm not sure whether you disagree or whether you weren't following when it happened, but the installer now adds a configuration setting to the default labconfig:

app_saved_configs = %(labscript_suite)s/userlib/app_saved_configs/%(experiment_name)s

As well as configuration setting in the [lyse] and [runmanager] sections:

autoload_config_file = %(app_saved_configs)s/lyse/lyse.ini

and

autoload_config_file = %(app_saved_configs)s/runmanager/runmanager.ini

So I thought this problem was resolved and that runviewer should use the <app_saved_configs>/runviewer directory, creating the app_saved_configs directory it if it doesn't exist for backward compatibility with config files that lack it.

Here is previous discussion:

content.raw:
Finally getting around to reviewing this!

Thoughts:

* The ordering of the channels are not preserved through save load. The most naive solution is to save using an `OrderedDict` instead. Probably need some logic to change the position of existing channels \(into the position that was saved\) if there are already loaded shots
* Should we only save channels that are ticked? Is there really a need to load in unticked channels? Because if they exist in the shot, they'll appear unticked anyway once that is loaded, and if they don't then why have them? I can maybe see a rare scenario where you want to save the position of an unticked channel, but the only way to cleanly solve all of these suggestions would be to allow the user to specify which channels to save, rather than saving them all \(which seems like a much bigger project, and should be deferred into an additional pull request - or just not done at all\)
content.html:
Finally getting around to reviewing this!

Thoughts:

  • The ordering of the channels are not preserved through save load. The most naive solution is to save using an OrderedDict instead. Probably need some logic to change the position of existing channels (into the position that was saved) if there are already loaded shots
  • Should we only save channels that are ticked? Is there really a need to load in unticked channels? Because if they exist in the shot, they'll appear unticked anyway once that is loaded, and if they don't then why have them? I can maybe see a rare scenario where you want to save the position of an unticked channel, but the only way to cleanly solve all of these suggestions would be to allow the user to specify which channels to save, rather than saving them all (which seems like a much bigger project, and should be deferred into an additional pull request - or just not done at all)

content.raw:
* I look into this and change it to preserve order.
* The idea behind saving unticked shots was to be able to quickly load another channel configuration without the need to manually untick the old one. So you could for example look at all your shutters and then all your laser intensity values after and not get them mixed. I would like to keep it this way.
content.html:
• I look into this and change it to preserve order.
  • The idea behind saving unticked shots was to be able to quickly load another channel configuration without the need to manually untick the old one. So you could for example look at all your shutters and then all your laser intensity values after and not get them mixed. I would like to keep it this way.

content.raw: Good point on the second item. I think there is probably a more optimal solution here, but I'm tired and can't be bothered working it out right now! \(so let's just leave item 2 as it is now\)
content.html: Good point on the second item. I think there is probably a more optimal solution here, but I'm tired and can't be bothered working it out right now! (so let's just leave item 2 as it is now)

content.raw:
I had a nasty bug where a bunch of exception windows were raised.

I loaded shot A, ticked some channels, reordered the channels, and saved the channel config. I then closed runviewer.

Then I opened runviewer, and loaded the saved channel configuration \(no shots loaded into runviewer yet\). I then loaded in shot B \(that had entirely unique channels\) and then loaded in shot C \(which had entirely unique channels to both A and B \). Then I displayed a couple of channels from shot B and C. All good so far. Then I loaded in shot A again, and enabled it. The exceptions I saw were:

    Traceback (most recent call last):
      File "C:\labscript_suite__venv_labscript27\runviewer\__main__.py", line 564, in update_plots
        for shot in self.plot_items[channel]:
    KeyError: u'central_MOT_shutter'

where `central_MOT_shutter` was the first channel in the list of channels \(so was part of the saved channels from shot A\) and was ticked.

Not entirely sure what is causing this! There is now a plot for the channel that raised the exception, but the other plots from shot A are not visible \(however those from shot B and C are\).
content.html:
I had a nasty bug where a bunch of exception windows were raised.

I loaded shot A, ticked some channels, reordered the channels, and saved the channel config. I then closed runviewer.

Then I opened runviewer, and loaded the saved channel configuration (no shots loaded into runviewer yet). I then loaded in shot B (that had entirely unique channels) and then loaded in shot C (which had entirely unique channels to both A and B ). Then I displayed a couple of channels from shot B and C. All good so far. Then I loaded in shot A again, and enabled it. The exceptions I saw were:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "C:\labscript_suite__venv_labscript27\runviewer\__main__.py", line 564, in update_plots
    for shot in self.plot_items[channel]:
KeyError: u'central_MOT_shutter'

where central_MOT_shutter was the first channel in the list of channels (so was part of the saved channels from shot A) and was ticked.

Not entirely sure what is causing this! There is now a plot for the channel that raised the exception, but the other plots from shot A are not visible (however those from shot B and C are).

content.raw: I'll look into this I might have a idea whats causing it.
content.html: I'll look into this I might have a idea whats causing it.
